Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; back skewed in shape with abraded details, only back of elytra and some features of clypeus survived; profile of back, high; at side, legs rather well-modelled with deeply undercut triangle; underside decorated with a very worn down motif representing recumbent winged sphinx, with two wings curved upwards; motif seems carved, not stamped; longitudinally pierced; glaze all gone; core dirty pale yellow, very much smoothed down.
Curator's comments: Scarabs and scaraboids with a winged sphinx motif depicted on the base belong to a standard group produced at the 'Scarab Factory' (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). The sphinx, with its two curved wings, recalls in its design the sphinx decorating the base of a scarab found in Perachora (Gorton 1996, 120, Type XXXIII C2). According to this better preserved examples, the sphinx holds a cone-shaped bread in its hands. Drawing published in Petrie 1886, pl. 37, 31. Gorton, A. F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, 'Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site', in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming, Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 31)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.019) (phase 3)
